conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a dark region.
The size and position of shadows depend on the positions of the light source, object, and surface.
Moving the light source backward increases the distance between the light source and the objects.
Increased distance affects both the size and position of the shadows.
As the light source moves farther away, the light rays become more parallel.
With more parallel light rays, shadows become smaller because the rays spread out less.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will become smaller.
The direction of light rays changes slightly when the light source moves backward.
Shadows will shift closer to the objects because the light rays hit from a more direct angle.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will move closer to their respective objects.
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will become smaller and shift closer to their objects.
